subject: Fix devstack with linuxbridge without l3 agent
commit_message:
Fix devstack with linuxbridge without l3 agent

The linuxbridge agent for Neutron expects that the public bridge will
already be created by the time it starts. On devstack, this only occurs
as part of the l3 agent configuration. If a compute node doesn't have an
l3 agent and is using a linuxbridge agent, then br-ex won't be created
and the process will not be able to start (causing stack.sh to fail).

This causes the gate-grenade-dsvm-neutron-linuxbridge-multinode-nv gate
to fail. To avoid the issue, skip the bridge mappings setup unless L3 is
configured. This is done in a backward compatible fashion: if localrc
uses the old q-l3 tags, the is_service_enabled neutron-l3 would not be
able to succeed.

Closes-Bug: #1643562

(cherry picked from commit 1c08b191fd04e028a8d908c9ccb4fdc536248c96)

subject: Handle MarkerNotFound from cell0 database
commit_message:
Handle MarkerNotFound from cell0 database

When listing instances in the cellv2 world we look them up
from three locations:

1. Build requests which exist before the instances are created
   in the cell database (after the scheduler picks a host to
   build the instance). Currently instances and build requests
   are both created before casting to conductor, but that's going
   away in Ocata with the support for multiple cellsv2 cells.
2. The cell0 database for instances which failed to get scheduled
   to a compute host (and therefore a cell).
3. The actual cell database that the instance lives in. Currently
   that's only a single traditional nova database, but could be one
   of multiple cellsv2 cells when we add that support in Ocata.

If a marker is passed in when listing instances, if the instance
lives in an actual cell database, we'll get a MarkerNotFound failure
from cell0 because the instance doesn't exist in cell0, but we check
cell0 before we check the cell database. This makes the instance
listing short-circuit and fail with a 400 from the REST API.

This patch simply handles the MarkerNotFound when listing instances
from the cell0 database and ignores it so we can continue onto the
cell database.

Closes-Bug: #1647464

subject: SRIOV: don't block report_state with device count
commit_message:
SRIOV: don't block report_state with device count

The device count process can be quite slow on a system with
lots of interfaces. Doing this during report_state can block
it long enough that the agent will be reported as dead and
bindings will fail.

This adjusts the logic to only update the configuration during
the normal device retrieval for the scan loop. This will leave
the report_state loop unblocked by the operation so the agent
doesn't get reported as dead (which blocks port binding).

Closes-Bug: #1648206

subject: Add json_plugin: simple way to post metrics to Monasca
commit_message:
Add json_plugin: simple way to post metrics to Monasca

This patch adds a plugin that reads metrics from JSON files. This
makes it very easy to integrate with Monasca -- instead of writing
a new plugin, simply write your metrics to a file.

The advantage of this mechanism is that:
- It's simple and easy to understand
- It is asynchronous with Monasca Agent. There are two technical
  advantages to this:
    - Your check does not need to run at same frequency as
      the agent.
    - If your check blocks, this does not affect other checks
      in the agent because the agent is not blocked.
- You can create the metrics as a side effect of doing other
  stuff. For example, a server process can write the JSON
  file while it is processing requests. With the normal plugin
  architecture, you need to write code that talks to your
  server process to access the metrics.
- You can write the check code in any language.

subject: Add janitor to cleanup orphaned fip ports
commit_message:
Add janitor to cleanup orphaned fip ports

This adds a janitor worker to the L3 DB module that
will run every 5 minutes looking for floating IP ports
with the device_id of 'PENDING'. If it finds any, it
will keep track of the port ID to see if any stay in
'PENDING' with the next iteration.

If the device ID is still PENDING after 5 minutes, it
means one of two things has happened. Either the server
died after creating the floating IP port, but before
creating the floating IP itself; or, it died after creating
the floating IP port and the floating IP record, but before
updating the device_id of the floating IP port to the
floating IP ID.

The janitor handles both cases by deleting the floating IP
port if it has no associated floating IP and by updating
the floating IP port device ID if it does have an associated
floating IP.

Related-Bug: #1540844
Closes-Bug: #1648098

subject: Add new attach/detach API calls
commit_message:
Add new attach/detach API calls

****** WIP *********
TODO:
1. Add the ack on connect/disconnect option for Nova
2. Unit tests
3. List/Get/Update Attachments
4. Figure out why os-brick/privsep pukes on unshelve
****** WIP *********

Latest modifications:
----------------------
10/6/16
  Added the no-connect flag to deal with attaching to
  shelved instances.  Uses an update_attachment to update
  and perform the connection on unshelve, also fixes the
  problem of detaching from a shelved instance that was
  never unshelved
---------------------

This patch aims to make the attach/detach process a bit
simpler and less prone to race conditions and solve
some confusion in it's usage.

For the first step we aren't implementing much, just
some new calls for attach and detach.  We'll call them
create/remove_attachment for now, and they'll just consolidate
all of the calls we used to make.

For example, instead of:
 1. reserve
 2. initialize
 3. attach

We'll just call create_attachment(volume, connector,
                                  instance_uuid, mountpoint)

For now that will simply call the existing initialize_connection
and attach methods, but the advantage here is it's a single call
for the consumer, and more importantly we can require all of the
various info we need up front.  This solves things like
multi-attach problems, because now we have all the info from
initialize, when we make the call to attach.

Eventually the old steps should be reimplemented and made more
efficient than they are currently, but if we get past this first
step we can have a stable, easy to use API to work off of that
shouldn't have to change AND best of all we don't break any
compatability.

subject: Improve scheduler host state's update model
commit_message:
Improve scheduler host state's update model

Current update model of scheduler host state has some issues. First, a
host state cache will be updated even if it is already the same with the
latest db data(i.e. HostState.db_updated = compute.updated_at =
HostState.db_updated). Second, the cache won't be updated even if db
data is newer in a specific case(i.e. HostState.db_updated <
compute.updated_at < HostState.updated).

This patch adds a timestamp to record when a host state cache is updated
by db(HostState.db_updated), and fixes the first issue. This complete
update model covers all 6 possible conditions:
1. compute_db_updated < cache_db_updated/cache_updated   -> return
2. cache_db_updated = cache_updated = compute_db_updated -> return
3. cache_db_updated = compute_db_updated < cache_updated -> return
4. cache_db_updated < compute_db_updated < cache_updated -> return
5. cache_db_updated < compute_db_updated = cache_updated -> update
6. cache_db_updated/cache_updated < compute_db_updated   -> update

However, this patch won't fix the second issue by setting #4 to
'-> update' because it will introduce much more unexpected retries due
to the losses of recent consumptions when refresh the host state,
causing a worse impact from the bug #1341420. A detailed analysis can
be found at https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1341420/comments/24

So the second issue is left unsolved because this leads to less
consumption losses and thus can reduce retries to minimum in
'one scheduler instance per cell' scenario. It should be solved after
consumptions are instantiated by claims during host state consumption,
which will be implemented in bp host-state-level-locking.

This patch also applies to IronicNodeState.

Partial-Bug: #1341420

When attaching a NFS volume, Nova returns the real file path in

subject: VMware: Omit exceptions during snapshot cleanup
commit_message:
VMware: Omit exceptions during snapshot cleanup

Rally scenario snapshot_server may fail occasionally at nova boot.
nova complains about image not ready when Rally tries to boot
a new instance with the snapshot after it waits the snapshot to
become ACTIVE.

When create a snapshot for an instance, VMware driver will create
a temporary VM, then export the root disk to Glance. The temporary
VM and the snapshot will be deleted when the image upload is done,
and the image will set to ACTIVE.

The ACTIVE status of an image is considered to be ready to go to
the next operation to boot a new instance from the image in Rally.

However, exception may be thrown during the cleanup operations.
nova-compute will try to delete the image in case of error.
The image status will be set to "deleting" when it happens.

In the mean time, when Rally drives nova to create a new instance
for the image, nova-api will check whether the image status is
"ACTIVE" but it may just have been set to "deleting" which causes
the boot operation to fail.

This commit will omit exceptions during the cleanup to prevent
the image status from changing once the upload is done.

Change-Id: Ia47a477b1f24d462d9c4e7085bdf187ab1f5b3ad
Closes-Bug: 1487950

This evacuation problem can be reproduced with deployment of VM and
corresponding host is shut down immediately before VIF active state in
InstanceInfoCache is updated to True from False for corresponding VM.
By examining compute log on source Host, you can determine if
InstanceInfoCache has been updated to active=True or not.

active it goes into stale state and any attempt to plug goes nowhere.

destination).

This patchset fixes this problem by adding logic to rebuild_instance
method in compute manager. It sets active state of all VIFs in the VM
to true. This is how it will be if VIF state becomes active on source
host before it goes down.

subject: Make RPCFixture support multiple connections
commit_message:
Make RPCFixture support multiple connections

For testing cells, we will need to track the driver instances that
we give out by url. This normally just works with a conventional
oslo.messaging driver, but the fake driver keeps internal data
structures for simulating its bus. If we end up with clients creating
a new instance of the driver in the rpc switching code, we'll never
be able to send messages to services because we'll always have
private/separate data structures.

So, this makes the fixture wrap the transport creation stuff
and unify references by url. In order to make this work, some
retooling of rpc.init() is done, which makes it more in line with
the recent additions we had for wrapping transport initialization
per connection anyway.

For now, a lot of our tests can't handle the possibility of
multiple RPC connections due to them looking at the global
transport_url configuration. So for the moment, even though this
makes the fixture support multiple independent connections, we
collapse any such attempts down to a single connection to the
default broker.

Note: this requires a fix in oslo.messaging 5.14.0

Depends-On: I01b6f5a20ea9752da46a546a908bd38cf11da681

subject: Handle MarkerNotFound from cell0 database
commit_message:
Handle MarkerNotFound from cell0 database

When listing instances in the cellv2 world we look them up
from three locations:

1. Build requests which exist before the instances are created
   in the cell database (after the scheduler picks a host to
   build the instance). Currently instances and build requests
   are both created before casting to conductor, but that's going
   away in Ocata with the support for multiple cellsv2 cells.
2. The cell0 database for instances which failed to get scheduled
   to a compute host (and therefore a cell).
3. The actual cell database that the instance lives in. Currently
   that's only a single traditional nova database, but could be one
   of multiple cellsv2 cells when we add that support in Ocata.

If a marker is passed in when listing instances, if the instance
lives in an actual cell database, we'll get a MarkerNotFound failure
from cell0 because the instance doesn't exist in cell0, but we check
cell0 before we check the cell database. This makes the instance
listing short-circuit and fail with a 400 from the REST API.

This patch simply handles the MarkerNotFound when listing instances
from the cell0 database and ignores it so we can continue onto the
cell database.

Closes-Bug: #1647464

Change-Id: I977497be262fb7f2333e32fb7313b29624323422
(cherry picked from commit 72d28ccd6e8ce8cf700891788f06578313b03c38)

subject: Fix default IPv6 BGP peer for BIRD
commit_message:
Fix default IPv6 BGP peer for BIRD

The jinja calculation of the BIRD BGP peer was failing intermittently
when IPv6 connectivity was not present.

Even though the IPv6 deployment was being detected correctly as
disabled by the role, the configuration task was failing to skip
consistently because the IPv6 peer address var could not be
resolved by Jinja.

This fixes the default IPv6 peer calculation to resolve to an empty
string when no IPv6 connectivity is present, which allows the
automatic IPv6 detection to skip the config task.

subject: Change initrd extraction method for partition undercloud
commit_message:
Change initrd extraction method for partition undercloud

There is a strange issue with the new image building process in
RDO where the host initramfs is ending up in the undercloud.qcow2,
but the host kernel is not. This initramfs does not match the
kernel from the CentOS cloud image used as a base, but instead is
for a newer kernel. The virt-get-kernel command just takes the
newest kernel and initramfs it can find in /boot/, which in this
case ends up with a mismatch.

Since the new image building process is just a converted
overcloud-full image, we can just copy-out the DIB extracted kernel
and initramfs from the undercloud to use for booting it. DIB seems
to be a bit smarter about how it extracts the kernel and initramfs,
so we do not get the same mismatch.

Change-Id: I66f6f168417377f313c003be70ee708310371f35
